summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P5264.08) detailing inmate telephone regulations, including procedures for call monitoring, list management, and restrictions. It establishes policy for inmate telephone privileges across all BOP institutions, with specific provisions for pretrial inmates and security monitoring. This document is a Bureau of Prisons policy (P5264.08) detailing procedures for inmate telephone use, monitoring, restrictions, and authorization of non-standard telephone systems. It outlines the responsibilities of inmates and staff, procedures for imposing telephone restrictions, and the role of the Warden and other officials in managing inmate communications.

keyFacts: The BOP provides inmates with telephone access to maintain community and family ties, but all calls (except properly placed calls to attorneys) are subject to monitoring for institutional security.
Inmates are limited to 300 minutes of telephone use per calendar month, with possible exceptions for good cause at the Warden's discretion.
The policy includes specific procedures for pretrial, holdover, and detainee inmates, noting that the 'Serious Telephone Abuse' Public Safety Factor does not apply to pretrial inmates.
Inmates can submit a telephone list of up to 30 numbers, with modifications allowed once per calendar month, and the Associate Warden has authority to deny or block numbers for security reasons.
The document rescinds the previous version (P5264.07 from 2002) and incorporates several policy changes, including removing references to the Washington v. Reno settlement agreement.
This is a standard Bureau of Prisons policy document (P5264.08) dated January 24, 2008, governing inmate telephone use, not a case-specific record related to Jeffrey Epstein.

The policy details strict procedures for monitoring inmate calls, authorizing non-standard telephones, and imposing restrictions, particularly for inmates with a 'Public Safety Factor (PSF) - Serious Telephone Abuse'.
The document is signed by Harley G. Lappin, who was the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the time.
Procedures require Warden approval for special telephone authorizations and restrictions, with notifications to Regional Directors and the Trust Fund Branch.
Inmates under investigation for telephone abuse can have restrictions imposed for 30-day periods, renewable with Warden approval.
